title: Cerebral Venous Thrombosis (CVT)
icd10: ** I67.6 (Nonpyogenic thrombosis of intracranial venous system)
I63.6 (Cerebral infarction due to cerebral venous thrombosis)
G08 (Intracranial and intraspinal phlebitis and thrombophlebitis)
scope: ** Diagnostic workup, acute anticoagulation, and long-term management of cerebral venous thrombosis. Covers all venous sinus locations (superior sagittal, transverse, sigmoid, straight, cavernous) and cortical/deep vein thrombosis. Includes management of associated hemorrhagic venous infarction, seizures, elevated ICP, and thrombophilia workup. Excludes cavernous sinus thrombosis from septic source (see infectious workup). For arterial ischemic stroke, see "Acute Ischemic Stroke" template. For subarachnoid hemorrhage, see "SAH" template.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Polycythemia, thrombocytosis, leukocytosis (infection/inflammation); HIT screen baseline
Metabolic screen; baseline for anticoagulation; hepatic function
Elevated in >90% CVT; normal D-dimer has high negative predictive value in low-suspicion cases; less useful if symptoms >2 weeks
Essential/Core Labs.target: Elevated (>500 ng/mL); normal does NOT exclude CVT if high suspicion

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Potential for hemorrhagic conversion or surgical intervention
Pregnancy/postpartum is major CVT risk factor; affects treatment choice
Septic CVT (cavernous sinus thrombosis from sinusitis/dental/orbital)
Sepsis screen if infectious etiology suspected

Thrombophilia/Hypercoagulable Workup.rationale: Most common inherited thrombophilia; increased CVT risk
Antithrombin deficiency; may be falsely low on heparin
Protein C deficiency; may be falsely low on warfarin or acute thrombosis

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology for CVT diagnosis confirmation, seizure management, and neurologic monitoring
Hematology for thrombophilia workup interpretation and anticoagulation duration guidance
Neurointerventional radiology for endovascular thrombectomy evaluation if deteriorating despite anticoagulation
Neurosurgery for decompressive hemicraniectomy evaluation if large hemorrhagic infarction with herniation risk
Ophthalmology/neuro-ophthalmology for papilledema assessment, visual field testing, and optic nerve monitoring
OB/GYN if pregnancy-related or postpartum CVT for anticoagulation coordination and delivery planning
ENT if septic CVT from sinusitis, mastoiditis, or dental source requiring surgical drainage
Hematology/oncology if myeloproliferative disorder (JAK2+, polycythemia vera) or malignancy identified
Physical therapy for mobility assessment and rehabilitation following neurologic deficits
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation if cognitive or motor deficits present
Social work for anticoagulation management support, disability resources, and family education

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately for sudden severe headache, new seizures, vision changes, weakness, or speech difficulty (may indicate extension or complication of CVT)
Take anticoagulation medication exactly as prescribed; do NOT miss doses; carry anticoagulation card
Avoid contact sports and activities with high fall/injury risk while anticoagulated
Report any signs of bleeding (blood in urine/stool, excessive bruising, prolonged bleeding from cuts, heavy menstruation) immediately
Do not take aspirin, ibuprofen, or other NSAIDs unless specifically directed by your physician while anticoagulated
INR monitoring appointments are critical if on warfarin -- do not miss them
Discuss contraception options with your physician as hormonal contraceptives may be contraindicated after CVT
Do not drive until cleared by neurology (seizure risk; visual field deficits)
Avoid dehydration (drink adequate fluids daily) as dehydration is a CVT risk factor
If planning pregnancy, discuss with both neurology and hematology for anticoagulation management (warfarin/DOACs contraindicated; LMWH required)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Discontinue oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) or hormone replacement therapy (HRT) permanently after CVT; discuss alternative contraception with gynecology
Smoking cessation to reduce prothrombotic risk
Adequate hydration (8+ glasses water daily) to reduce venous stasis
Avoid prolonged immobilization; use compression stockings during long travel
Maintain healthy weight to reduce prothrombotic risk
Address modifiable risk factors identified in thrombophilia workup (folate for hyperhomocysteinemia, phlebotomy for polycythemia)

disposition.criteria: Neurologically stable; therapeutic anticoagulation achieved; seizures controlled; no significant hemorrhagic infarction; adequate outpatient follow-up arranged (neurology, hematology, ophthalmology); patient/family educated on anticoagulation management and warning signs

New CVT diagnosis requiring anticoagulation initiation; seizures requiring treatment; elevated ICP requiring medical management; hemorrhagic venous infarction (small/moderate); diagnostic workup pending

Large hemorrhagic infarction with mass effect; GCS ≤12; refractory seizures or status epilepticus; malignant cerebral edema with herniation risk; hemodynamic instability; requires invasive ICP monitoring; post-endovascular procedure
Neurointerventional capability not available (for endovascular thrombectomy); neurosurgery not available (for decompressive hemicraniectomy); requires ICU care not available at current facility

All patients: neurology within 1-2 weeks; hematology within 1 month (thrombophilia results); ophthalmology within 2-4 weeks if papilledema; anticoagulation clinic (if on warfarin); repeat MRV at 3-6 months
New or worsening headache; new seizures; new neurologic deficits; signs of bleeding on anticoagulation; pregnancy (requires anticoagulation modification)
